Award.AwardTitle: Conference: SnowPAC 2016: The Galaxy/Halo Connection; Snowbird, Utah; March 13-18, 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
Funds are provided for participant support for the 6th annual Snowbird Workshop on Particle Astrophysics, Astronomy, and Cosmology (SnowPAC 2016), organized by the Department of Physics and Astronomy of The University of Utah. The award will support participation (via lodging and registration subsidy) by 30 individuals who would otherwise be unable to attend the meeting, with a particular emphasis on broadening participation by junior researchers and groups traditionally underrepresented in astronomy and astrophysics.

The SnowPAC workshop is an international meeting that reviews recent developments in particle astrophysics, dark matter, dark energy, astronomy, and cosmology. It seeks to establish new connections between these disciplines and establish new collaborative ties between individuals working in these research areas.

The SnowPAC 2016 conference is a topical conference on "The Galaxy-Halo Connection," and will bring together members of the observational, theoretical, and numerical simulation communities. This conference will provide a venue to compare the results of the latest simulations to analytic models, and to the observed clustering of matter. It will provide direction for future efforts in the field of galaxy evolution and clustering of large-scale structure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF award provided support for participants in the conference "SnowPAC 2016: The Galaxy/Halo Connection" held at Snowbird, UT from March 13, 2016 through March 18, 2016. Through NSF funds, support was given to 37 of 80 participants, including 21 graduate students and ten women. The NSF funding was crucial in enabling early career scientists and scientists form underrepresented groups to attend this international conference. The funding given to each attendee traveling from outside of Utah $430/person. Funding of $50/person per day was provided to cover the registration fees of local graduate students who attended daily sessions.

The conference was the primary conference on the galaxy halo connection in 2016. It brought together members of the observational, theoretical, and numerical simulation communities to discuss the connection between galaxy evolution and cosmology.  The conference provided a venue to compare the results of the latest simulations to analytic models and to the observed clustering of matter.  Over the course of the week, the talks helped to draw the connection between galaxy evolution on the smallest scales and implications
for constraints on dark energy, modified gravity, neutrino masses and the properties of inflation.

The venue was held in an informal setting that is inclusive of graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, early career scientists, and senior researchers. Digital copies of every talk were posted to a public webpage within one hour of the presentation, thus enabling discussion and collaboration beyond the conference venue.
